6861 @public
6862 def all_roots(f, multiple=True, radicals=True, extension=False):
6863     """ 
6864     Returns the real and complex roots of ``f`` with multiplicities. 
6865  
6866     Explanation 
6867     =========== 
6868  
6869     Finds all real and complex roots of a univariate polynomial with rational 
6870     coefficients of any degree exactly. The roots are represented in the form 
6871     given by :func:`~.rootof`. This is equivalent to using :func:`~.rootof` to 
6872     find each of the indexed roots. 
6873  
6874     Examples 
6875     ======== 
6876  
6877     >>> from sympy import all_roots 
6878     >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 
6879  
6880     >>> print(all_roots(x**3 + 1)) 
6881     [-1, 1/2 - sqrt(3)*I/2, 1/2 + sqrt(3)*I/2] 
6882  
6883     Simple radical formulae are used in some cases but the cubic and quartic 
6884     formulae are avoided. Instead most non-rational roots will be represented 
6885     as :class:`~.ComplexRootOf`: 
6886  
6887     >>> print(all_roots(x**3 + x + 1)) 
6888     [CRootOf(x**3 + x + 1, 0), CRootOf(x**3 + x + 1, 1), CRootOf(x**3 + x + 1, 2)] 
6889  
6890     All roots of any polynomial with rational coefficients of any degree can be 
6891     represented using :py:class:`~.ComplexRootOf`. The use of 
6892     :py:class:`~.ComplexRootOf` bypasses limitations on the availability of 
6893     radical formulae for quintic and higher degree polynomials _[1]: 
6894  
6895     >>> p = x**5 - x - 1 
6896     >>> for r in all_roots(p): print(r) 
6897     CRootOf(x**5 - x - 1, 0) 
6898     CRootOf(x**5 - x - 1, 1) 
6899     CRootOf(x**5 - x - 1, 2) 
6900     CRootOf(x**5 - x - 1, 3) 
6901     CRootOf(x**5 - x - 1, 4) 
6902     >>> [r.evalf(3) for r in all_roots(p)] 
6903     [1.17, -0.765 - 0.352*I, -0.765 + 0.352*I, 0.181 - 1.08*I, 0.181 + 1.08*I] 
6904  
6905     Irrational algebraic coefficients are handled by :func:`all_roots` 
6906     if `extension=True` is set. 
6907  
6908     >>> from sympy import sqrt, expand 
6909     >>> p = expand((x - sqrt(2))*(x - sqrt(3))) 
6910     >>> print(p) 
6911     x**2 - sqrt(3)*x - sqrt(2)*x + sqrt(6) 
6912     >>> all_roots(p) 
6913     Traceback (most recent call last): 
6914     ... 
6915     NotImplementedError: sorted roots not supported over EX 
6916     >>> all_roots(p, extension=True) 
6917     [sqrt(2), sqrt(3)] 
6918  
6919     Algebraic coefficients can be complex as well. 
6920  
6921     >>> from sympy import I 
6922     >>> all_roots(x**2 - I, extension=True) 
6923     [-sqrt(2)/2 - sqrt(2)*I/2, sqrt(2)/2 + sqrt(2)*I/2] 
6924     >>> all_roots(x**2 - sqrt(2)*I, extension=True) 
6925     [-2**(3/4)/2 - 2**(3/4)*I/2, 2**(3/4)/2 + 2**(3/4)*I/2] 
6926  
6927     Transcendental coefficients cannot currently be handled by 
6928     :func:`all_roots`. In the case of algebraic or transcendental coefficients 
6929     :func:`~.ground_roots` might be able to find some roots by factorisation: 
6930  
6931     >>> from sympy import ground_roots 
6932     >>> ground_roots(p, x, extension=True) 
6933     {sqrt(2): 1, sqrt(3): 1} 
6934  
6935     If the coefficients are numeric then :func:`~.nroots` can be used to find 
6936     all roots approximately: 
6937  
6938     >>> from sympy import nroots 
6939     >>> nroots(p, 5) 
6940     [1.4142, 1.732] 
6941  
6942     If the coefficients are symbolic then :func:`sympy.polys.polyroots.roots` 
6943     or :func:`~.ground_roots` should be used instead: 
6944  
6945     >>> from sympy import roots, ground_roots 
6946     >>> p = x**2 - 3*x*y + 2*y**2 
6947     >>> roots(p, x) 
6948     {y: 1, 2*y: 1} 
6949     >>> ground_roots(p, x) 
6950     {y: 1, 2*y: 1} 
6951  
6952     Parameters 
6953     ========== 
6954  
6955     f : :class:`~.Expr` or :class:`~.Poly` 
6956         A univariate polynomial with rational (or ``Float``) coefficients. 
6957     multiple : ``bool`` (default ``True``). 
6958         Whether to return a ``list`` of roots or a list of root/multiplicity 
6959         pairs. 
6960     radicals : ``bool`` (default ``True``) 
6961         Use simple radical formulae rather than :py:class:`~.ComplexRootOf` for 
6962         some irrational roots. 
6963     extension: ``bool`` (default ``False``) 
6964         Whether to construct an algebraic extension domain before computing 
6965         the roots. Setting to ``True`` is necessary for finding roots of a 
6966         polynomial with (irrational) algebraic coefficients but can be slow. 
6967  
6968     Returns 
6969     ======= 
6970  
6971     A list of :class:`~.Expr` (usually :class:`~.ComplexRootOf`) representing 
6972     the roots is returned with each root repeated according to its multiplicity 
6973     as a root of ``f``. The roots are always uniquely ordered with real roots 
6974     coming before complex roots. The real roots are in increasing order. 
6975     Complex roots are ordered by increasing real part and then increasing 
6976     imaginary part. 
6977  
6978     If ``multiple=False`` is passed then a list of root/multiplicity pairs is 
6979     returned instead. 
6980  
6981     If ``radicals=False`` is passed then all roots will be represented as 
6982     either rational numbers or :class:`~.ComplexRootOf`. 
6983  
6984     See also 
6985     ======== 
6986  
6987     Poly.all_roots: 
6988         The underlying :class:`Poly` method used by :func:`~.all_roots`. 
6989     rootof: 
6990         Compute a single numbered root of a univariate polynomial. 
6991     real_roots: 
6992         Compute all the real roots using :func:`~.rootof`. 
6993     ground_roots: 
6994         Compute some roots in the ground domain by factorisation. 
6995     nroots: 
6996         Compute all roots using approximate numerical techniques. 
6997     sympy.polys.polyroots.roots: 
6998         Compute symbolic expressions for roots using radical formulae. 
6999  
7000     References 
7001     ========== 
7002  
7003     .. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abel%E2%80%93Ruffini_theorem 
7004     """
7005     try:
7006         if isinstance(f, Poly):
7007             if extension and not f.domain.is_AlgebraicField:
7008                 F = Poly(f.expr, extension=True)
7009             else:
7010                 F = f
7011         else:
7012             if extension:
7013                 F = Poly(f, extension=True)
7014             else:
7015                 F = Poly(f, greedy=False)
7016 
7017         if not isinstance(f, Poly) and not F.gen.is_Symbol:
7018             # root of sin(x) + 1 is -1 but when someone
7019             # passes an Expr instead of Poly they may not expect
7020             # that the generator will be sin(x), not x
7021             raise PolynomialError("generator must be a Symbol")
7022     except GeneratorsNeeded:
7023         raise PolynomialError(
7024             "Cannot compute real roots of %s, not a polynomial" % f)
7025 
7026     return F.all_roots(multiple=multiple, radicals=radicals)
7027 
7028 
7029 @public
7030 def real_roots(f, multiple=True, radicals=True, extension=False):
7031     """ 
7032     Returns the real roots of ``f`` with multiplicities. 
7033  
7034     Explanation 
7035     =========== 
7036  
7037     Finds all real roots of a univariate polynomial with rational coefficients 
7038     of any degree exactly. The roots are represented in the form given by 
7039     :func:`~.rootof`. This is equivalent to using :func:`~.rootof` or 
7040     :func:`~.all_roots` and filtering out only the real roots. However if only 
7041     the real roots are needed then :func:`real_roots` is more efficient than 
7042     :func:`~.all_roots` because it computes only the real roots and avoids 
7043     costly complex root isolation routines. 
7044  
7045     Examples 
7046     ======== 
7047  
7048     >>> from sympy import real_roots 
7049     >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 
7050  
7051     >>> real_roots(2*x**3 - 7*x**2 + 4*x + 4) 
7052     [-1/2, 2, 2] 
7053     >>> real_roots(2*x**3 - 7*x**2 + 4*x + 4, multiple=False) 
7054     [(-1/2, 1), (2, 2)] 
7055  
7056     Real roots of any polynomial with rational coefficients of any degree can 
7057     be represented using :py:class:`~.ComplexRootOf`: 
7058  
7059     >>> p = x**9 + 2*x + 2 
7060     >>> print(real_roots(p)) 
7061     [CRootOf(x**9 + 2*x + 2, 0)] 
7062     >>> [r.evalf(3) for r in real_roots(p)] 
7063     [-0.865] 
7064  
7065     All rational roots will be returned as rational numbers. Roots of some 
7066     simple factors will be expressed using radical or other formulae (unless 
7067     ``radicals=False`` is passed). All other roots will be expressed as 
7068     :class:`~.ComplexRootOf`. 
7069  
7070     >>> p = (x + 7)*(x**2 - 2)*(x**3 + x + 1) 
7071     >>> print(real_roots(p)) 
7072     [-7, -sqrt(2), CRootOf(x**3 + x + 1, 0), sqrt(2)] 
7073     >>> print(real_roots(p, radicals=False)) 
7074     [-7, CRootOf(x**2 - 2, 0), CRootOf(x**3 + x + 1, 0), CRootOf(x**2 - 2, 1)] 
7075  
7076     All returned root expressions will numerically evaluate to real numbers 
7077     with no imaginary part. This is in contrast to the expressions generated by 
7078     the cubic or quartic formulae as used by :func:`~.roots` which suffer from 
7079     casus irreducibilis [1]_: 
7080  
7081     >>> from sympy import roots 
7082     >>> p = 2*x**3 - 9*x**2 - 6*x + 3 
7083     >>> [r.evalf(5) for r in roots(p, multiple=True)] 
7084     [5.0365 - 0.e-11*I, 0.33984 + 0.e-13*I, -0.87636 + 0.e-10*I] 
7085     >>> [r.evalf(5) for r in real_roots(p, x)] 
7086     [-0.87636, 0.33984, 5.0365] 
7087     >>> [r.is_real for r in roots(p, multiple=True)] 
7088     [None, None, None] 
7089     >>> [r.is_real for r in real_roots(p)] 
7090     [True, True, True] 
7091  
7092     Using :func:`real_roots` is equivalent to using :func:`~.all_roots` (or 
7093     :func:`~.rootof`) and filtering out only the real roots: 
7094  
7095     >>> from sympy import all_roots 
7096     >>> r = [r for r in all_roots(p) if r.is_real] 
7097     >>> real_roots(p) == r 
7098     True 
7099  
7100     If only the real roots are wanted then using :func:`real_roots` is faster 
7101     than using :func:`~.all_roots`. Using :func:`real_roots` avoids complex root 
7102     isolation which can be a lot slower than real root isolation especially for 
7103     polynomials of high degree which typically have many more complex roots 
7104     than real roots. 
7105  
7106     Irrational algebraic coefficients are handled by :func:`real_roots` 
7107     if `extension=True` is set. 
7108  
7109     >>> from sympy import sqrt, expand 
7110     >>> p = expand((x - sqrt(2))*(x - sqrt(3))) 
7111     >>> print(p) 
7112     x**2 - sqrt(3)*x - sqrt(2)*x + sqrt(6) 
7113     >>> real_roots(p) 
7114     Traceback (most recent call last): 
7115     ... 
7116     NotImplementedError: sorted roots not supported over EX 
7117     >>> real_roots(p, extension=True) 
7118     [sqrt(2), sqrt(3)] 
7119  
7120     Transcendental coefficients cannot currently be handled by 
7121     :func:`real_roots`. In the case of algebraic or transcendental coefficients 
7122     :func:`~.ground_roots` might be able to find some roots by factorisation: 
7123  
7124     >>> from sympy import ground_roots 
7125     >>> ground_roots(p, x, extension=True) 
7126     {sqrt(2): 1, sqrt(3): 1} 
7127  
7128     If the coefficients are numeric then :func:`~.nroots` can be used to find 
7129     all roots approximately: 
7130  
7131     >>> from sympy import nroots 
7132     >>> nroots(p, 5) 
7133     [1.4142, 1.732] 
7134  
7135     If the coefficients are symbolic then :func:`sympy.polys.polyroots.roots` 
7136     or :func:`~.ground_roots` should be used instead. 
7137  
7138     >>> from sympy import roots, ground_roots 
7139     >>> p = x**2 - 3*x*y + 2*y**2 
7140     >>> roots(p, x) 
7141     {y: 1, 2*y: 1} 
7142     >>> ground_roots(p, x) 
7143     {y: 1, 2*y: 1} 
7144  
7145     Parameters 
7146     ========== 
7147  
7148     f : :class:`~.Expr` or :class:`~.Poly` 
7149         A univariate polynomial with rational (or ``Float``) coefficients. 
7150     multiple : ``bool`` (default ``True``). 
7151         Whether to return a ``list`` of roots or a list of root/multiplicity 
7152         pairs. 
7153     radicals : ``bool`` (default ``True``) 
7154         Use simple radical formulae rather than :py:class:`~.ComplexRootOf` for 
7155         some irrational roots. 
7156     extension: ``bool`` (default ``False``) 
7157         Whether to construct an algebraic extension domain before computing 
7158         the roots. Setting to ``True`` is necessary for finding roots of a 
7159         polynomial with (irrational) algebraic coefficients but can be slow. 
7160  
7161     Returns 
7162     ======= 
7163  
7164     A list of :class:`~.Expr` (usually :class:`~.ComplexRootOf`) representing 
7165     the real roots is returned. The roots are arranged in increasing order and 
7166     are repeated according to their multiplicities as roots of ``f``. 
7167  
7168     If ``multiple=False`` is passed then a list of root/multiplicity pairs is 
7169     returned instead. 
7170  
7171     If ``radicals=False`` is passed then all roots will be represented as 
7172     either rational numbers or :class:`~.ComplexRootOf`. 
7173  
7174     See also 
7175     ======== 
7176  
7177     Poly.real_roots: 
7178         The underlying :class:`Poly` method used by :func:`real_roots`. 
7179     rootof: 
7180         Compute a single numbered root of a univariate polynomial. 
7181     all_roots: 
7182         Compute all real and non-real roots using :func:`~.rootof`. 
7183     ground_roots: 
7184         Compute some roots in the ground domain by factorisation. 
7185     nroots: 
7186         Compute all roots using approximate numerical techniques. 
7187     sympy.polys.polyroots.roots: 
7188         Compute symbolic expressions for roots using radical formulae. 
7189  
7190     References 
7191     ========== 
7192  
7193     .. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casus_irreducibilis 
7194     """
7195     try:
7196         if isinstance(f, Poly):
7197             if extension and not f.domain.is_AlgebraicField:
7198                 F = Poly(f.expr, extension=True)
7199             else:
7200                 F = f
7201         else:
7202             if extension:
7203                 F = Poly(f, extension=True)
7204             else:
7205                 F = Poly(f, greedy=False)
7206 
7207         if not isinstance(f, Poly) and not F.gen.is_Symbol:
7208             # root of sin(x) + 1 is -1 but when someone
7209             # passes an Expr instead of Poly they may not expect
7210             # that the generator will be sin(x), not x
7211             raise PolynomialError("generator must be a Symbol")
7212     except GeneratorsNeeded:
7213         raise PolynomialError(
7214             "Cannot compute real roots of %s, not a polynomial" % f)
7215 
7216     return F.real_roots(multiple=multiple, radicals=radicals)

7324 @public
7325 def cancel(f, *gens, _signsimp=True, **args):
7326     """ 
7327     Cancel common factors in a rational function ``f``. 
7328  
7329     Examples 
7330     ======== 
7331  
7332     >>> from sympy import cancel, sqrt, Symbol, together 
7333     >>> from sympy.abc import x 
7334     >>> A = Symbol('A', commutative=False) 
7335  
7336     >>> cancel((2*x**2 - 2)/(x**2 - 2*x + 1)) 
7337     (2*x + 2)/(x - 1) 
7338     >>> cancel((sqrt(3) + sqrt(15)*A)/(sqrt(2) + sqrt(10)*A)) 
7339     sqrt(6)/2 
7340  
7341     Note: due to automatic distribution of Rationals, a sum divided by an integer 
7342     will appear as a sum. To recover a rational form use `together` on the result: 
7343  
7344     >>> cancel(x/2 + 1) 
7345     x/2 + 1 
7346     >>> together(_) 
7347     (x + 2)/2 
7348     """
7349     from sympy.simplify.simplify import signsimp
7350     from sympy.polys.rings import sring
7351     options.allowed_flags(args, ['polys'])
7352 
7353     f = sympify(f)
7354     if _signsimp:
7355         f = signsimp(f)
7356     opt = {}
7357     if 'polys' in args:
7358         opt['polys'] = args['polys']
7359 
7360     if not isinstance(f, Tuple):
7361         if f.is_Number or isinstance(f, Relational) or not isinstance(f, Expr):
7362             return f
7363         f = factor_terms(f, radical=True)
7364         p, q = f.as_numer_denom()
7365 
7366     elif len(f) == 2:
7367         p, q = f
7368         if isinstance(p, Poly) and isinstance(q, Poly):
7369             opt['gens'] = p.gens
7370             opt['domain'] = p.domain
7371             opt['polys'] = opt.get('polys', True)
7372         p, q = p.as_expr(), q.as_expr()
7373     else:
7374         raise ValueError('unexpected argument: %s' % f)
7375 
7376     from sympy.functions.elementary.piecewise import Piecewise
7377     try:
7378         if f.has(Piecewise):
7379             raise PolynomialError()
7380         R, (F, G) = sring((p, q), *gens, **args)
7381         if not R.ngens:
7382             if not isinstance(f, Tuple):
7383                 return f.expand()
7384             else:
7385                 return S.One, p, q
7386     except PolynomialError as msg:
7387         if f.is_commutative and not f.has(Piecewise):
7388             raise PolynomialError(msg)
7389         # Handling of noncommutative and/or piecewise expressions
7390         if f.is_Add or f.is_Mul:
7391             c, nc = sift(f.args, lambda x:
7392                 x.is_commutative is True and not x.has(Piecewise),
7393                 binary=True)
7394             nc = [cancel(i) for i in nc]
7395             return f.func(cancel(f.func(*c)), *nc)
7396         else:
7397             reps = []
7398             pot = preorder_traversal(f)
7399             next(pot)
7400             for e in pot:
7401                 if isinstance(e, BooleanAtom) or not isinstance(e, Expr):
7402                     continue
7403                 try:
7404                     reps.append((e, cancel(e)))
7405                     pot.skip()  # this was handled successfully
7406                 except NotImplementedError:
7407                     pass
7408             return f.xreplace(dict(reps))
7409 
7410     c, (P, Q) = 1, F.cancel(G)
7411     if opt.get('polys', False) and 'gens' not in opt:
7412         opt['gens'] = R.symbols
7413 
7414     if not isinstance(f, Tuple):
7415         return c*(P.as_expr()/Q.as_expr())
7416     else:
7417         P, Q = P.as_expr(), Q.as_expr()
7418         if not opt.get('polys', False):
7419             return c, P, Q
7420         else:
7421             return c, Poly(P, *gens, **opt), Poly(Q, *gens, **opt)
7422

7424 @public
7425 def reduced(f, G, *gens, **args):
7426     """ 
7427     Reduces a polynomial ``f`` modulo a set of polynomials ``G``. 
7428  
7429     Given a polynomial ``f`` and a set of polynomials ``G = (g_1, ..., g_n)``, 
7430     computes a set of quotients ``q = (q_1, ..., q_n)`` and the remainder ``r`` 
7431     such that ``f = q_1*g_1 + ... + q_n*g_n + r``, where ``r`` vanishes or ``r`` 
7432     is a completely reduced polynomial with respect to ``G``. 
7433  
7434     Examples 
7435     ======== 
7436  
7437     >>> from sympy import reduced 
7438     >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 
7439  
7440     >>> reduced(2*x**4 + y**2 - x**2 + y**3, [x**3 - x, y**3 - y]) 
7441     ([2*x, 1], x**2 + y**2 + y) 
7442  
7443     """
7444     options.allowed_flags(args, ['polys', 'auto'])
7445 
7446     try:
7447         polys, opt = parallel_poly_from_expr([f] + list(G), *gens, **args)
7448     except PolificationFailed as exc:
7449         raise ComputationFailed('reduced', 0, exc)
7450 
7451     domain = opt.domain
7452     retract = False
7453 
7454     if opt.auto and domain.is_Ring and not domain.is_Field:
7455         opt = opt.clone({"domain": domain.get_field()})
7456         retract = True
7457 
7458     from sympy.polys.rings import xring
7459     _ring, _ = xring(opt.gens, opt.domain, opt.order)
7460 
7461     for i, poly in enumerate(polys):
7462         poly = poly.set_domain(opt.domain).rep.to_dict()
7463         polys[i] = _ring.from_dict(poly)
7464 
7465     Q, r = polys[0].div(polys[1:])
7466 
7467     Q = [Poly._from_dict(dict(q), opt) for q in Q]
7468     r = Poly._from_dict(dict(r), opt)
7469 
7470     if retract:
7471         try:
7472             _Q, _r = [q.to_ring() for q in Q], r.to_ring()
7473         except CoercionFailed:
7474             pass
7475         else:
7476             Q, r = _Q, _r
7477 
7478     if not opt.polys:
7479         return [q.as_expr() for q in Q], r.as_expr()
7480     else:
7481         return Q, r
7482

7484 @public
7485 def groebner(F, *gens, **args):
7486     """ 
7487     Computes the reduced Groebner basis for a set of polynomials. 
7488  
7489     Use the ``order`` argument to set the monomial ordering that will be 
7490     used to compute the basis. Allowed orders are ``lex``, ``grlex`` and 
7491     ``grevlex``. If no order is specified, it defaults to ``lex``. 
7492  
7493     For more information on Groebner bases, see the references and the docstring 
7494     of :func:`~.solve_poly_system`. 
7495  
7496     Examples 
7497     ======== 
7498  
7499     Example taken from [1]. 
7500  
7501     >>> from sympy import groebner 
7502     >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 
7503  
7504     >>> F = [x*y - 2*y, 2*y**2 - x**2] 
7505  
7506     >>> groebner(F, x, y, order='lex') 
7507     GroebnerBasis([x**2 - 2*y**2, x*y - 2*y, y**3 - 2*y], x, y, 
7508                   domain='ZZ', order='lex') 
7509     >>> groebner(F, x, y, order='grlex') 
7510     GroebnerBasis([y**3 - 2*y, x**2 - 2*y**2, x*y - 2*y], x, y, 
7511                   domain='ZZ', order='grlex') 
7512     >>> groebner(F, x, y, order='grevlex') 
7513     GroebnerBasis([y**3 - 2*y, x**2 - 2*y**2, x*y - 2*y], x, y, 
7514                   domain='ZZ', order='grevlex') 
7515  
7516     By default, an improved implementation of the Buchberger algorithm is 
7517     used. Optionally, an implementation of the F5B algorithm can be used. The 
7518     algorithm can be set using the ``method`` flag or with the 
7519     :func:`sympy.polys.polyconfig.setup` function. 
7520  
7521     >>> F = [x**2 - x - 1, (2*x - 1) * y - (x**10 - (1 - x)**10)] 
7522  
7523     >>> groebner(F, x, y, method='buchberger') 
7524     GroebnerBasis([x**2 - x - 1, y - 55], x, y, domain='ZZ', order='lex') 
7525     >>> groebner(F, x, y, method='f5b') 
7526     GroebnerBasis([x**2 - x - 1, y - 55], x, y, domain='ZZ', order='lex') 
7527  
7528     References 
7529     ========== 
7530  
7531     1. [Buchberger01]_ 
7532     2. [Cox97]_ 
7533  
7534     """
7535     return GroebnerBasis(F, *gens, **args)
7536

7538 @public
7539 def is_zero_dimensional(F, *gens, **args):
7540     """ 
7541     Checks if the ideal generated by a Groebner basis is zero-dimensional. 
7542  
7543     The algorithm checks if the set of monomials not divisible by the 
7544     leading monomial of any element of ``F`` is bounded. 
7545  
7546     References 
7547     ========== 
7548  
7549     David A. Cox, John B. Little, Donal O'Shea. Ideals, Varieties and 
7550     Algorithms, 3rd edition, p. 230 
7551  
7552     """
7553     return GroebnerBasis(F, *gens, **args).is_zero_dimensional

7556 @public
7557 class GroebnerBasis(Basic):
7558     """Represents a reduced Groebner basis. """
7559 
7560     def __new__(cls, F, *gens, **args):
7561         """Compute a reduced Groebner basis for a system of polynomials. """
7562         options.allowed_flags(args, ['polys', 'method'])
7563 
7564         try:
7565             polys, opt = parallel_poly_from_expr(F, *gens, **args)
7566         except PolificationFailed as exc:
7567             raise ComputationFailed('groebner', len(F), exc)
7568 
7569         from sympy.polys.rings import PolyRing
7570         ring = PolyRing(opt.gens, opt.domain, opt.order)
7571 
7572         polys = [ring.from_dict(poly.rep.to_dict()) for poly in polys if poly]
7573 
7574         G = _groebner(polys, ring, method=opt.method)
7575         G = [Poly._from_dict(g, opt) for g in G]
7576 
7577         return cls._new(G, opt)
7578 
7579     @classmethod
7580     def _new(cls, basis, options):
7581         obj = Basic.__new__(cls)
7582 
7583         obj._basis = tuple(basis)
7584         obj._options = options
7585 
7586         return obj
7587 
7588     @property
7589     def args(self):
7590         basis = (p.as_expr() for p in self._basis)
7591         return (Tuple(*basis), Tuple(*self._options.gens))
7592 
7593     @property
7594     def exprs(self):
7595         return [poly.as_expr() for poly in self._basis]
7596 
7597     @property
7598     def polys(self):
7599         return list(self._basis)
7600 
7601     @property
7602     def gens(self):
7603         return self._options.gens
7604 
7605     @property
7606     def domain(self):
7607         return self._options.domain
7608 
7609     @property
7610     def order(self):
7611         return self._options.order
7612 
7613     def __len__(self):
7614         return len(self._basis)
7615 
7616     def __iter__(self):
7617         if self._options.polys:
7618             return iter(self.polys)
7619         else:
7620             return iter(self.exprs)
7621 
7622     def __getitem__(self, item):
7623         if self._options.polys:
7624             basis = self.polys
7625         else:
7626             basis = self.exprs
7627 
7628         return basis[item]
7629 
7630     def __hash__(self):
7631         return hash((self._basis, tuple(self._options.items())))
7632 
7633     def __eq__(self, other):
7634         if isinstance(other, self.__class__):
7635             return self._basis == other._basis and self._options == other._options
7636         elif iterable(other):
7637             return self.polys == list(other) or self.exprs == list(other)
7638         else:
7639             return False
7640 
7641     def __ne__(self, other):
7642         return not self == other
7643 
7644     @property
7645     def is_zero_dimensional(self):
7646         """ 
7647         Checks if the ideal generated by a Groebner basis is zero-dimensional. 
7648  
7649         The algorithm checks if the set of monomials not divisible by the 
7650         leading monomial of any element of ``F`` is bounded. 
7651  
7652         References 
7653         ========== 
7654  
7655         David A. Cox, John B. Little, Donal O'Shea. Ideals, Varieties and 
7656         Algorithms, 3rd edition, p. 230 
7657  
7658         """
7659         def single_var(monomial):
7660             return sum(map(bool, monomial)) == 1
7661 
7662         exponents = Monomial([0]*len(self.gens))
7663         order = self._options.order
7664 
7665         for poly in self.polys:
7666             monomial = poly.LM(order=order)
7667 
7668             if single_var(monomial):
7669                 exponents *= monomial
7670 
7671         # If any element of the exponents vector is zero, then there's
7672         # a variable for which there's no degree bound and the ideal
7673         # generated by this Groebner basis isn't zero-dimensional.
7674         return all(exponents)
7675 
7676     def fglm(self, order):
7677         """ 
7678         Convert a Groebner basis from one ordering to another. 
7679  
7680         The FGLM algorithm converts reduced Groebner bases of zero-dimensional 
7681         ideals from one ordering to another. This method is often used when it 
7682         is infeasible to compute a Groebner basis with respect to a particular 
7683         ordering directly. 
7684  
7685         Examples 
7686         ======== 
7687  
7688         >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 
7689         >>> from sympy import groebner 
7690  
7691         >>> F = [x**2 - 3*y - x + 1, y**2 - 2*x + y - 1] 
7692         >>> G = groebner(F, x, y, order='grlex') 
7693  
7694         >>> list(G.fglm('lex')) 
7695         [2*x - y**2 - y + 1, y**4 + 2*y**3 - 3*y**2 - 16*y + 7] 
7696         >>> list(groebner(F, x, y, order='lex')) 
7697         [2*x - y**2 - y + 1, y**4 + 2*y**3 - 3*y**2 - 16*y + 7] 
7698  
7699         References 
7700         ========== 
7701  
7702         .. [1] J.C. Faugere, P. Gianni, D. Lazard, T. Mora (1994). Efficient 
7703                Computation of Zero-dimensional Groebner Bases by Change of 
7704                Ordering 
7705  
7706         """
7707         opt = self._options
7708 
7709         src_order = opt.order
7710         dst_order = monomial_key(order)
7711 
7712         if src_order == dst_order:
7713             return self
7714 
7715         if not self.is_zero_dimensional:
7716             raise NotImplementedError("Cannot convert Groebner bases of ideals with positive dimension")
7717 
7718         polys = list(self._basis)
7719         domain = opt.domain
7720 
7721         opt = opt.clone({
7722             "domain": domain.get_field(),
7723             "order": dst_order,
7724         })
7725 
7726         from sympy.polys.rings import xring
7727         _ring, _ = xring(opt.gens, opt.domain, src_order)
7728 
7729         for i, poly in enumerate(polys):
7730             poly = poly.set_domain(opt.domain).rep.to_dict()
7731             polys[i] = _ring.from_dict(poly)
7732 
7733         G = matrix_fglm(polys, _ring, dst_order)
7734         G = [Poly._from_dict(dict(g), opt) for g in G]
7735 
7736         if not domain.is_Field:
7737             G = [g.clear_denoms(convert=True)[1] for g in G]
7738             opt.domain = domain
7739 
7740         return self._new(G, opt)
7741 
7742     def reduce(self, expr, auto=True):
7743         """ 
7744         Reduces a polynomial modulo a Groebner basis. 
7745  
7746         Given a polynomial ``f`` and a set of polynomials ``G = (g_1, ..., g_n)``, 
7747         computes a set of quotients ``q = (q_1, ..., q_n)`` and the remainder ``r`` 
7748         such that ``f = q_1*f_1 + ... + q_n*f_n + r``, where ``r`` vanishes or ``r`` 
7749         is a completely reduced polynomial with respect to ``G``. 
7750  
7751         Examples 
7752         ======== 
7753  
7754         >>> from sympy import groebner, expand, Poly 
7755         >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 
7756  
7757         >>> f = 2*x**4 - x**2 + y**3 + y**2 
7758         >>> G = groebner([x**3 - x, y**3 - y]) 
7759  
7760         >>> G.reduce(f) 
7761         ([2*x, 1], x**2 + y**2 + y) 
7762         >>> Q, r = _ 
7763  
7764         >>> expand(sum(q*g for q, g in zip(Q, G)) + r) 
7765         2*x**4 - x**2 + y**3 + y**2 
7766         >>> _ == f 
7767         True 
7768  
7769         # Using Poly input 
7770         >>> f_poly = Poly(f, x, y) 
7771         >>> G = groebner([Poly(x**3 - x), Poly(y**3 - y)]) 
7772  
7773         >>> G.reduce(f_poly) 
7774         ([Poly(2*x, x, y, domain='ZZ'), Poly(1, x, y, domain='ZZ')], Poly(x**2 + y**2 + y, x, y, domain='ZZ')) 
7775  
7776         """
7777         if isinstance(expr, Poly):
7778 
7779             if expr.gens != self._options.gens:
7780                 raise ValueError("Polynomial generators don't match Groebner basis generators")
7781             poly = expr.set_domain(self._options.domain)
7782         else:
7783 
7784             poly = Poly._from_expr(expr, self._options)
7785 
7786         polys = [poly] + list(self._basis)
7787 
7788         opt = self._options
7789         domain = opt.domain
7790 
7791         retract = False
7792 
7793         if auto and domain.is_Ring and not domain.is_Field:
7794             opt = opt.clone({"domain": domain.get_field()})
7795             retract = True
7796 
7797         from sympy.polys.rings import xring
7798         _ring, _ = xring(opt.gens, opt.domain, opt.order)
7799 
7800         for i, poly in enumerate(polys):
7801             poly = poly.set_domain(opt.domain).rep.to_dict()
7802             polys[i] = _ring.from_dict(poly)
7803 
7804         Q, r = polys[0].div(polys[1:])
7805 
7806         Q = [Poly._from_dict(dict(q), opt) for q in Q]
7807         r = Poly._from_dict(dict(r), opt)
7808 
7809         if retract:
7810             try:
7811                 _Q, _r = [q.to_ring() for q in Q], r.to_ring()
7812             except CoercionFailed:
7813                 pass
7814             else:
7815                 Q, r = _Q, _r
7816 
7817         if not opt.polys:
7818             return [q.as_expr() for q in Q], r.as_expr()
7819         else:
7820             return Q, r
7821 
7822     def contains(self, poly):
7823         """ 
7824         Check if ``poly`` belongs the ideal generated by ``self``. 
7825  
7826         Examples 
7827         ======== 
7828  
7829         >>> from sympy import groebner 
7830         >>> from sympy.abc import x, y 
7831  
7832         >>> f = 2*x**3 + y**3 + 3*y 
7833         >>> G = groebner([x**2 + y**2 - 1, x*y - 2]) 
7834  
7835         >>> G.contains(f) 
7836         True 
7837         >>> G.contains(f + 1) 
7838         False 
7839  
7840         """
7841         return self.reduce(poly)[1] == 0
7842 
7843 
7844 @public
7845 def poly(expr, *gens, **args):
7846     """ 
7847     Efficiently transform an expression into a polynomial. 
7848  
7849     Examples 
7850     ======== 
7851  
7852     >>> from sympy import poly 
7853     >>> from sympy.abc import x 
7854  
7855     >>> poly(x*(x**2 + x - 1)**2) 
7856     Poly(x**5 + 2*x**4 - x**3 - 2*x**2 + x, x, domain='ZZ') 
7857  
7858     """
7859     options.allowed_flags(args, [])
7860 
7861     def _poly(expr, opt):
7862         terms, poly_terms = [], []
7863 
7864         for term in Add.make_args(expr):
7865             factors, poly_factors = [], []
7866 
7867             for factor in Mul.make_args(term):
7868                 if factor.is_Add:
7869                     poly_factors.append(_poly(factor, opt))
7870                 elif factor.is_Pow and factor.base.is_Add and \
7871                         factor.exp.is_Integer and factor.exp >= 0:
7872                     poly_factors.append(
7873                         _poly(factor.base, opt).pow(factor.exp))
7874                 else:
7875                     factors.append(factor)
7876 
7877             if not poly_factors:
7878                 terms.append(term)
7879             else:
7880                 product = poly_factors[0]
7881 
7882                 for factor in poly_factors[1:]:
7883                     product = product.mul(factor)
7884 
7885                 if factors:
7886                     factor = Mul(*factors)
7887 
7888                     if factor.is_Number:
7889                         product *= factor
7890                     else:
7891                         product = product.mul(Poly._from_expr(factor, opt))
7892 
7893                 poly_terms.append(product)
7894 
7895         if not poly_terms:
7896             result = Poly._from_expr(expr, opt)
7897         else:
7898             result = poly_terms[0]
7899 
7900             for term in poly_terms[1:]:
7901                 result = result.add(term)
7902 
7903             if terms:
7904                 term = Add(*terms)
7905 
7906                 if term.is_Number:
7907                     result += term
7908                 else:
7909                     result = result.add(Poly._from_expr(term, opt))
7910 
7911         return result.reorder(*opt.get('gens', ()), **args)
7912 
7913     expr = sympify(expr)
7914 
7915     if expr.is_Poly:
7916         return Poly(expr, *gens, **args)
7917 
7918     if 'expand' not in args:
7919         args['expand'] = False
7920 
7921     opt = options.build_options(gens, args)
7922 
7923     return _poly(expr, opt)
7924 
7925 
7926 def named_poly(n, f, K, name, x, polys):
7927     r"""Common interface to the low-level polynomial generating functions 
7928     in orthopolys and appellseqs. 
7929  
7930     Parameters 
7931     ========== 
7932  
7933     n : int 
7934         Index of the polynomial, which may or may not equal its degree. 
7935     f : callable 
7936         Low-level generating function to use. 
7937     K : Domain or None 
7938         Domain in which to perform the computations. If None, use the smallest 
7939         field containing the rationals and the extra parameters of x (see below). 
7940     name : str 
7941         Name of an arbitrary individual polynomial in the sequence generated 
7942         by f, only used in the error message for invalid n. 
7943     x : seq 
7944         The first element of this argument is the main variable of all 
7945         polynomials in this sequence. Any further elements are extra 
7946         parameters required by f. 
7947     polys : bool, optional 
7948         If True, return a Poly, otherwise (default) return an expression. 
7949     """
7950     if n < 0:
7951         raise ValueError("Cannot generate %s of index %s" % (name, n))
7952     head, tail = x[0], x[1:]
7953     if K is None:
7954         K, tail = construct_domain(tail, field=True)
7955     poly = DMP(f(int(n), *tail, K), K)
7956     if head is None:
7957         poly = PurePoly.new(poly, Dummy('x'))
7958     else:
7959         poly = Poly.new(poly, head)
7960     return poly if polys else poly.as_expr()
7961
